answers.text: please engage your Technical Solution Manager for further assistance.

qas.question: What error has been reported in Microsoft SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS)?

answers.text: The error "Data type is not recognized" is reported in the logs.

qas.question: How can I fix the "Data type is not recognized" error in SSIS?

answers.text: adjust the Stored Procedure to not return a UNIQUEIDENTIFIER data type, alternatively, convert the data type into a string within the procedure before returning it.

paragraphs.context:
The IBM Watson service is reporting a failure during data processing, showing an error message that the input document type is not supported. To resolve this, please try modifying the document type configuration or reach out to the IBM Support team via https://www.ibm.com/support/home/. You could also raise a Request For Enhancement at https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/rfe/. If the issue persists, please engage your Technical Solution Manager for further assistance.

In another incidence, an error has been noted in Microsoft SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) when dealing with specific data types. The error "Data type is not recognized" is reported in the logs. The cause has been identified as SSIS not recognizing the UNIQUEIDENTIFIER data type from an SQL Server stored procedure. To troubleshoot this problem, you should adjust the Stored Procedure to not return a UNIQUEIDENTIFIER data type, alternatively, convert the data type into a string within the procedure before returning it. If the help needed goes beyond your technical capability, consider reaching out to Microsoft Support.

qas.question: What error does the IBM messaging system report?

answers.text: Unsupported message format is being treated as text.

qas.question: What's the cause of this error in the IBM messaging system?

answers.text: MIME is not a valid format for an incoming message queue using the IBM MQ adapter.

qas.question: How can I diagnose this problem?

answers.text: LastErrorMsg() reports 'Failed to process the incoming message queue' and the MQ adapter log reports 'Unsupported message format is being treated as text.'

qas.question: How to resolve this problem in the IBM messaging system?

answers.text: Reconfigure the incoming message queue system to NOT accept a MIME format.

qas.question: What is the recommended version to upgrade the IBM MQ system?

answers.text: To resolve the issue, upgrade IBM MQ system to version 7.5, 8.0 or newer.

qas.question: Where can I get updates for the IBM MQ system?

answers.text: IBM MQ downloads and updates [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg27045388]

paragraphs.context:
SYMPTOM
The IBM messaging system reports the following error: Unsupported message format is being treated as text.

CAUSE
MIME is not a valid format for an incoming message queue using the IBM MQ adapter.

ENVIRONMENT
IBM WebSphere MQ/ IBM MQ adapter on any valid execution platform

DIAGNOSING THE PROBLEM
LastErrorMsg() reports 'Failed to process the incoming message queue' and the MQ adapter log reports 'Unsupported message format is being treated as text.'

RESOLVING THE PROBLEM
Reconfigure the incoming message queue system to NOT accept a MIME format.
Example Context:

To resolve the issue, upgrade IBM MQ system to version 7.5, 8.0 or newer.

RELATED INFORMATION 
IBM MQ downloads and updates [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg27045388] Context:

qas.question: How does a standard forward proxy server behave?

answers.text: Most standard forward proxy servers anticipate different request formats, based on whether they are routing non-SSL or SSL requests.

qas.question: How can Non-SSL or SSL Proxy requests be handled?

answers.text: For Non-SSL Proxy requests, an XML Firewall can be used in the HTTP Options tab to configure the Proxy Host and Port, or a Multi-Protocol Gateway can be used to set up an HTTP Proxy Policy in the User Agent. For SSL Proxy requests, the Multi-Protocol Gateway should be used in the User Agent's HTTP Proxy Policy to implement the CONNECT method for SSL Tunneling.

Context Change:
ROOT CAUSE
Most standard forward proxy servers anticipate different request formats, based on whether they are routing non-SSL or SSL requests. Non-SSL requests might come in the form of GET hostname:port/URI, whereas for SSL requests, the proxy servers, more often than not, are configured to channel the request from the client to the server.

ISSUE RESOLUTION
For Non-SSL Proxy requests, an XML Firewall can be used in the HTTP Options tab to configure the Proxy Host and Port, or a Multi-Protocol Gateway can be used to set up an HTTP Proxy Policy in the User Agent. For SSL Proxy requests, the Multi-Protocol Gateway should be used in the User Agent's HTTP Proxy Policy to implement the CONNECT method for SSL Tunneling. Note that the XML Firewall service is not designed to utilize the CONNECT method for SSL Tunneling.

qas.question: What can cause issues with the execution of certain commands in MySQL databases when working with Python?

answers.text: a SQL query in Python to retrieve data from a MySQL database might fail due to the incorrect use of SELECT syntax.

qas.question: How can users resolve problems they face while retrieving data from a MySQL database using Python?

answers.text: users need to use the MySQL Connector, a library for connecting a Python program to a MySQL database. When writing a SQL query, the syntax should be SELECT column_name FROM table_name, and this query should be executed using the fetchall() function.

qas.question: What should be done to prevent errors or ineffective commands when using MySQL databases with Python?

answers.text: Efforts should be made to adhere to the respective syntax standards

qas.question: What can cause user challenges when querying for documents that contain certain types of data in MongoDB databases?

answers.text: Suppose a document has an array field, and the user wants to query documents based on values within that array.

qas.question: How can users overcome the issue of querying documents based on values within an array in MongoDB databases?

answers.text: users can use the $in operator within a query, which matches any value in an array.

qas.question: Is there a specific example of how to use the $in operator to find documents where the array field contains a specific value in MongoDB?

answers.text: For example, to find documents where the array field contains a value "example", the query would be {field: {$in: ["example"]}}.

paragraphs.context:
CAUSE

Sometimes while working with MySQL databases, users might face an issue with the execution of certain commands. Languages like Python require certain mechanisms to interact with MySQL databases. For instance, a SQL query in Python to retrieve data from a MySQL database might fail due to the incorrect use of SELECT syntax.

RESOLVING THE PROBLEM

To retrieve any data from a MySQL database using Python, users need to use the MySQL Connector, a library for connecting a Python program to a MySQL database. When writing a SQL query, the syntax should be SELECT column_name FROM table_name, and this query should be executed using the fetchall() function. Efforts should be made to adhere to the respective syntax standards, as failure to do so can result in errors or ineffective commands.

Example Context:

CAUSE

While using MongoDB databases, there could be instances where users might face challenges in querying for documents that contain certain types of data. Suppose a document has an array field, and the user wants to query documents based on values within that array.

ANSWER

To overcome this issue in MongoDB, users can use the $in operator within a query, which matches any value in an array. For example, to find documents where the array field contains a value "example", the query would be {field: {$in: ["example"]}}. This specific method of querying is useful when dealing with array fields in documents. It is also recommended to refer to MongoDB's official documentation for more detailed information about querying documents.

paragraphs.context:
Configuring alternate names for MQMB/WTX. 

For instance, you may want to use directory shortcuts when working with various IBM libraries on your operating system, such as macOS, Linux, or Unix.

Here's an example of how you could do it:

First, navigate to the usr/lib directory using terminal:
```bash
cd /usr/lib
```
Next, create symbolic links to the necessary IBM libraries:
```bash
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libcph1*
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libmqm_r.so
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libmqmcs_r.so
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libmqic_r.so
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libdpstd.so
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libmqz_r.so
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libcom.so
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libcpsm.so
```
Remember: The required libraries can be identified by using the following command:
```bash
dump -H $MQMBHOME/platform/unix/mqm_ping
```
If there are any updated versions of the necessary libraries, it's recommended to create a symbolic link to the newer version. For example, run:
```bash
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libcph1.1.so
```
Instead of:
```bash
ln -s /opt/IBM/MQMB/v8/lib/libcph1.so
```
After applying any Fix pack for MQMB core, it's advised to recreate the symbolic links.

Cross-reference information Segment Product Component Platform Version Edition Systems and Asset Management IBM MQMB Ping Unix All versions

qas.question: What happens if errors related to virtualization services or tools occur during system startup in a non-virtualized environment?

answers.text: In a non-virtualized environment, if particular errors occur during the system startup, and these errors are strictly related to virtualization services or tools, it can be assumed that these errors don’t corrupt the system functions or capabilities. Therefore, unless the system plans to incorporate virtualization features in the future, these errors can be overlooked.

paragraphs.context:
Initiate the process of setting up environment variables such as JAVA_HOME and PATH. This can be done using the following steps:

e.g,

# cd /etc/profile.d
# touch setenv.sh
# chmod +x setenv.sh
# vi setenv.sh

After running vi setenv.sh, you should add below lines to the file:

export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/jre
export PATH=$PATH:$JAVA_HOME/bin

Save and close the file. Now, modify the SYSTEMD file by running:

# vi /etc/systemd/system.conf

Here, add these lines:

DefaultLimitNOFILE=65535
DefaultLimitNPROC=65535

Save the file and then reboot the system. These changes should set up the required environment variables and system configurations correctly.

Please be aware, if you upgrade your system software or apply any update, you might need to recreate these links and variable settings as they could be overridden.

Note: Remember that the path `/usr/lib/jvm/jre` is an example. Replace it with your actual Java path. Also, DefaultLimitNOFILE and DefaultLimitNPROC values depend on your system requirements, so adjust them accordingly. 

Parallel to this,
In a non-virtualized environment, if particular errors occur during the system startup, and these errors are strictly related to virtualization services or tools, it can be assumed that these errors don’t corrupt the system functions or capabilities. Therefore, unless the system plans to incorporate virtualization features in the future, these errors can be overlooked.

qas.question: How can I learn more about Python's memory management and garbage collection?

follow the 'Additional Info' section's links. Here's how you can check the Python interpreter's maximum memory uptake allowance: 

a) Open your command line or terminal and go to the <INST>/lib/python<version> folder 
b) Run this command: python -Xmx2048m hello
- If Python is comfortable with 2GB assignment, "ModuleNotFoundError" for hello will be the error you'll receive
- An alternative error message might surface, typically "MemoryError", if Python doesn't accept it
- To find the limit, gradually push the Xmx value higher until a problem arises
- In terms of a 32-bit Python interpreter, exceeding 2048m is deemed inadvisable, whereas, for 64-bit systems, it can be up to half of your total physical memory.

Restart the server once you adjust these settings so that the changes become operative.

paragraphs.context:
1 PetaByte equals 1024*1024*1024*1024 kilobytes. Visit the links in the 'Further Information' section to understand more about computer memory and storage. Here's how to check your computer's maximum RAM capacity:

a) Open command line / shell script and navigate to C://Windows/System32
b) Run this command: wmic memorychip get capacity 
- If your system supports the amount of RAM installed, it should display the capacity
- If it does not support this amount, an error message will appear

For a 32-bit operating system, maximum RAM support is usually 4GB, while a 64-bit OS can support more than 4GB. After upgrading your RAM, ensure to restart your computer for changes to take effect.

FURTHER INFORMATION PC Memory Explained [http://www.pcmag.com/encyclopedia/term/37725/memory]

Checking RAM Capacity [http://www.computerhope.com/issues/ch000149.htm].

Context:

Let's consider, you are trying to remove a user from your server access list:

REMOVE USER('user account') TYPE(ADMIN) PERMISSION(DENY) ACTION(REMOVE)
  
You are faced with the following error:

ERROR1: User account not found

You attempt the original command to delete the user's account, altering the action to REMOVE:

REMOVE USER('user account') TYPE(ADMIN) PERMISSION(DENY) LOCATION('ALL') ACTION(REMOVE)
  
ERROR2: Parameter not suitable for this action on a user authentication record

The attribute LOCATION is not a valid parameter for the REMOVE action. Therefore, removing the LOCATION attribute allowed the following command to successfully remove the user record :

REMOVE USER('user account') TYPE(ADMIN) PERMISSION(DENY) ACTION(REMOVE) SUCCESS: Server user authentication record removed.

Refer to:
Server Authentication Guide [http://www.serverguidelines.com/]

Commands for Server Management [http://www.systemcommands.com/].

Usage notes
The following table shows which parameters are valid for each value of ACTION:
.Action Parameter ADD or REMOVE REMOVEALL
USER X X X 
TYPE X X X 
PERMISSION X X X 
ACTION X X X 
LOCATION X X
TIME X X 
ALIAS X X

answers.text:
you receive a AMQ8886 error message: Not an accepted parameter for this type of action on a channel authentication record.

The ADDROPTS attribute is not a valid parameter for a REMOVE action

qas.question: What was the modification made to the command to successfully remove the channel authentication record?

answers.text: by erasing this attribute, the subsequent command operated successfully to erase the record: SET CHLAUTH(OUR.CHANNEL) TYPE(ADDRESSMAP) CLNTADDR('192.0.2.0') INTERFACE('IPv4') ACTION(REMOVE).

qas.question: What are the mentioned alternative solutions if no matching user is found on the current LDAP server?

answers.text: you can manually create a corresponding user. Alternatively, utilizing the HR Loader tool to import the users that are linked with the new LDAP server is an option.

paragraphs.context:
Occasionally, you encounter this error: SET CHLAUTH(OUR.CHANNEL) TYPE(ADDRESSMAP) CLNTADDR('192.0.2.0') ACTION(REMOVE) AMQ8893: Channel authentication record not located. 

You decided to execute the initial command that generated the record, but this time with the ACTION as REMOVE: SET CHLAUTH(OUR.CHANNEL) TYPE(ADDRESSMAP) CLNTADDR('192.0.2.0') ADDROPTS(MAP) MCAUSER('admin_1') INTERFACE('IPv4') ACTION(REMOVE). However, you receive a AMQ8886 error message: Not an accepted parameter for this type of action on a channel authentication record.

The ADDROPTS attribute is not a valid parameter for a REMOVE action (refer to table below).

Therefore, by erasing this attribute, the subsequent command operated successfully to erase the record: SET CHLAUTH(OUR.CHANNEL) TYPE(ADDRESSMAP) CLNTADDR('192.0.2.0') INTERFACE('IPv4') ACTION(REMOVE). The AMQ8878: WebSphere MQ channel authentication record has been established.

See: WebSphere MQ 7.5.0 > IBM MQ > Resource > Administration guide > MQSC guideline > The MQSC commands > SET CHLAUTH [http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_7.5.0/com.ibm.mq.ref.adm.doc/q086630_.htm]

qas.question: What is the cause of 'Unexpected exception' error during the replication process from Master Portal to Virtual Portal?

answers.text: This happens because the Admin user exists on the Master Portal but not in the Realm attached to the Virtual Portal.

qas.question: To whom does the error 'MemberNotFound' occur in the replication process?

answers.text: An Admin user who is also the Domain Admin retrieved through UserManagementServiceImpl.getPortalAdministrator() would not have access to the Virtual Portal.

qas.question: How can the replication error from Master Portal to Virtual Portal be rectified?

answers.text: the Admin user has to be made accessible to both the Master and the Virtual Portals for the successful syndication to occur.

qas.question: What are the challenges faced in software infrastructures like IBM MQ?

answers.text: These complications often stem from complex interactions between different components within the platforms used.

qas.question: What is the key to effectively handle errors in complex software infrastructures?

answers.text: fully understand the integration points and mechanisms and apply the necessary corrective measures effectively.

paragraphs.context:
Context: The process of replicating content from Master Portal to Virtual Portal using different realms can cause errors. An example of this issue can be observed when two distinct realms (DC=company1, DC=example) are mapped to the Master Portal and a Virtual Portal (DC=company2, DC=example) respectively. If a replication process (i.e., syndication) is initiated, an error occurs, which manifests as an 'Unexpected exception' with an indication of 'MemberNotFound'. This happens because the Admin user exists on the Master Portal but not in the Realm attached to the Virtual Portal. An Admin user who is also the Domain Admin retrieved through UserManagementServiceImpl.getPortalAdministrator() would not have access to the Virtual Portal. To rectify this, the Admin user has to be made accessible to both the Master and the Virtual Portals for the successful syndication to occur. 

Context: Software infrastructures such as IBM MQ face issues when there's cross-referencing within diverse business integrations. These complications often stem from complex interactions between different components within the platforms used. In the scenario of IBM MQ Advanced for Developers, for instance, a unique problem might be encountered in the way MQ functions within states or segments. Immediate feedback and troubleshooting help users avoid errors in future operation, thereby improving overall system efficiency. The key is to fully understand the integration points and mechanisms and apply the necessary corrective measures effectively.

paragraphs.context:
During the operational period, we've found that Oracle's ODBC drivers work optimally with the system.sql.updateMethod = SEQ configuration. However, the memory allocation for this setup remains ingrained or cached until the server is deactivated or the table is deleted. One can check this by analyzing "sqlpd -sql showsql -memoryAllocation 2 ordered -allsql". Mostly, new memory allocations are initiated from File 1702862303 LOC 1045 and LOC 1035. 

For instance:

On Day 1:
SQL Memory Consumers in Server Memory Set:
PoolID | PoolName | TotalSize(Bytes) | %Bytes | TotalCount | %Count | LOC | File 
    2  |  sqlh    | 2802503298       | 52.03  | 61001      |  8.15  | 1045 | 1702862303
    2  |  sqlh    | 2107926532       | 40.85  | 61001      |  8.15  | 1035 | 1702862303
    2  |  sqlh    | 360107960        | 7.36   | 190321     | 23.08  | 2325 | 1325216715
    2  |  sqlh    | 41060252         | 0.84   | 179296     | 22.64  | 3259 | 1325216715

On Day 2:
SQL Memory Consumers in Server Memory Set:
PoolID | PoolName | TotalSize(Bytes) | %Bytes | TotalCount | %Count | LOC | File 
    2  |  sqlh    | 2942641820       | 52.52  | 64836      |  7.79  | 1045 | 1702862303
    2  |  sqlh    | 2257394356       | 40.95  | 64836      |  7.79  | 1035 | 1702862303
    2  |  sqlh    | 396841992        | 7.64   | 196844     | 22.98  | 2325 | 1325216715
    2  |  sqlh    | 45061088         | 0.89   | 185834     | 22.48  | 3259 | 1325216715

Please note that LOC values may differ based on various versions presented. The aforementioned LOC is appropriate for V10.2F12. By gathering "sqlpd -d showsql -sqlStats -allsql", you can observe that the number of sql entries continuously augment.

Addressing the issue:
Understand that this is a typical event, seeing as all tables on the server are retrieved at least once, the enhancement in memory will discontinue.

paragraphs.context:
In this context, we notice a recurring trend in memory resource usage within a particular database. Through the usage and observation of "db2pd -db showdb -memblocks 2 sort -alldbp" tool, it is evident that a majority of the new memory allocations are being dictated by the files found in LOC 1025 and LOC 1015. Over time, the overall resource consumption in Database memory set is seen to be increasing. 

DETECTING AND ADDRESSING THE ISSUE

Next, towards addressing this concern, consider deploying "db2pd -d showdb -tcbstats -alldbp". This intervention will enable tracking the increase in tcb entries. It's vital to note that variations in the LOC depend on the version in use; the given LOC is applicable to V9.7FP11 only. 

MANAGING AND OPTIMIZING MEMORY 

Expectedly, once each table in the database has been accessed at least once, the surge in memory allocation should stabilize. Hence, the initial memory increase should not be a cause for concern as it's part of the process. 

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

paragraphs.context:
User responsibility is placed on mitigating any existing or prospective security breaches concerning their platform. An Arabic version of this information can be obtained as well [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21981234] Referral details Section Product Component Environment Version Release Enterprise Connectivity IBM MQ Not Unfitting AIX, HP-UX, Linux, Solaris, Windows 11.0, 10.0 PRODUCT ALIAS/SYNONYM MQ IBM MQ.

Following context refers to setting up Apache HTTP Server on a Linux System. If you download the Apache HTTP Server from the Linux Distribution Repository, some features may differ from the version provided on the Apache HTTP Server official website. Before starting the following process, ensure that you download and install the Apache HTTP Server via the repository provided by your Linux distribution. 
1- Begin by editing the httpd.conf file found in the Apache HTTP Server install path. The path to the file should look similar to /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf.
 On a supported Linux 64-bit platform with openJDK 11.0.8 installed in /opt/IBM/ITM/, this will result in the following block being appended into the /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf.
#-----Configurator of DC Begin------
SetEnv LD_LIBRARY_PATH /opt/IBM/ITM/TMAITM6/j2eedc/7.1.1.0.0/toolkit/lib/linux64:${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}
SetEnv JAVA_OPTS "-Xmx256m -Xms64m -Duser.timezone=GMT"
#-----Configurator of DC End--------
Remember to check whether DC is started correctly when Apache HTTP Server is started, even though Apache HTTP Server is intended to run as a Linux Service in the future.
2- Using a text editor, open the /etc/sysconfig/httpd file.
3- Copy the values from the httpd.conf file for LD_LIBRARY_PATH and JAVA_OPTS, and place them respectively into the httpd file.
4- Update the system's environment variable LD_LIBRARY_PATH with the same value as defined in /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf:<DC_home>/toolkit/lib/<linux_arch>
Considering our Linux 64-bit example:/opt/IBM/ITM/TMAITM6/j2eedc/7.1.1.0.0/toolkit/lib/linux64.
Despite slight variations in updating system environment variables across different Linux distributions, it mostly can be done from System Settings-->Advanced-->Environment Variables-->Edit.
5- Finally, restart the Linux system.

qas.question: How do you update the System Environment Variable PATH?

answers.text:
Add the same value set for PATH in startup.bat to the System Environment Variable PATH in the System Environment Variables:

<DC_home>\toolkit\lib\<win64>

For example, in our Windows 64-bit platform: C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\toolkit\lib\win64. This can be performed from Control Panel > Advanced System Settings > Environment Variables > Edit System Variable: Path

qas.question: What should be done after setting up the startup.bat file and updating the System Environment Variable PATH?

answers.text: Lastly, restart the Windows system.

paragraphs.context:
When setting up Apache Tomcat via Eclipse environment, rather than base distribution, certain inbuilt command line operations and startup scripts might be missing, disabling you to execute the below procedure smoothly. If you have installed Eclipse Mars on a Windows 64-bit platform with JDK 8.1.0.0.0 in C:\JAVA\SDK\, and Tomcat 9 with the supported version of JRE, steps should be followed to add the following section into the <Eclipse_home>\bin\ startup.bat file:

REM -----Initial Configuration Setup Start----------
set PATH=C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\toolkit\lib\win64;%PATH%
set JAVA_OPTS=-Xbootclasspath/p:C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\toolkit\lib\bcm-bootstrap.jar -Xbootclasspath/p:C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\itcamdc\lib\probe-bootstrap.jar -Xbootclasspath/p:C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\itcamdc\lib\ext\tomcat\tomcat.bcm.jar -agentlib:am_sun_16=C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\runtime\tomcat9\dc.env.properties -Xloggc:C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\runtime\tomcat9\gc.log -XX:-TraceClassLoading -XX:-TraceClassUnloading -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote -Dsun.lang.ClassLoader.allowArraySyntax=true %JAVA_OPTS%
REM -----Initial Configuration Setup End----------

Now, the correct start of the setup can be checked when you launch the Tomcat via Eclipse. 

Proceed by right-clicking on the Tomcat icon on the Windows taskbar and selecting Configure. As the Apache Tomcat properties window pop up, navigate to the Java™ tab. Extract the value for JAVA_OPTS from the startup.bat file and paste it into the Java Options text box in the Apache Tomcat Properties window.

Add the same value set for PATH in startup.bat to the System Environment Variable PATH in the System Environment Variables:

<DC_home>\toolkit\lib\<win64>

For example, in our Windows 64-bit platform: C:\JAVA\SDK\JMARS\j2eserver\8.1.0.0.0\toolkit\lib\win64. This can be performed from Control Panel > Advanced System Settings > Environment Variables > Edit System Variable: Path, considering the Windows version being used.

Lastly, restart the Windows system.

For diagnostics, you may want to gather the outputs for the following CLI commands:
show clock
show version
show javaversion
show sensors
configservice show
test hardware
test software

paragraphs.context:
When dealing with Java applications, it's essential to have the correct version of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) installed on your server. If the specific version needed by your application is not present, it could result in runtime issues. Additionally, you may also need to set the classpath correctly to pick the application's required classes and libraries.

Similarly, when managing a Ubuntu Linux server, it's crucial to ensure the operating system has the specific version of libc6 library that your application requires. A mismatch in the version could lead to application functionalities not working as expected. Hence, always validate the version of libraries before and after updating the Linux server.

qas.question: During file transfer, how can some files be sent?

answers.text: during a file transfer process, some files may be sent directly through an application server, like: servername/myapp/documents/files.pdf.

qas.question: How can certain files be directly served from a server?

answers.text: certain files are directed through the web application functioning on the server like: /servername/myapp/photos/landscape.jpg.

qas.question: Why it is crucial to understand the different routes files take?

answers.text: It's crucial to comprehend the different routes files take to effectively manage potential security threats.

paragraphs.context: In the realm of digital security, users are often accountable for evaluating the effects of any existing or potential security risks on their systems. For instance, during a file transfer process, some files may be sent directly through an application server, like: servername/myapp/documents/files.pdf. However, using certain techniques, some files can be directly served from a server, such as: /servername/myapp/static/textfile.pdf. On the other hand, certain files are directed through the web application functioning on the server like: /servername/myapp/photos/landscape.jpg. It's crucial to comprehend the different routes files take to effectively manage potential security threats.

qas.question: What causes the issue with IBM® Cognos® Analytics Studio in IBM Jazz for Service Management's Dashboard Application Services Hub and Tivoli® Common Reporting Version 3.2?

answers.text: Launching Tivoli Common Reporting from Dashboard Application Services Hub triggers browser mode compatibility issues, causing Cognos Analytics Studio functions to malfunction.

qas.question: What is the underlying reason for this issue?

answers.text: The IBM Jazz for Service Management framework contains the Dashboard Application Services Hub service and the Tivoli Common Reporting service.

qas.question: What version of Firefox is supported by Dashboard Application Services Hub?

answers.text: Dashboard Application Services Hub supports Firefox Quantum v60

qas.question: What version of Firefox is supported by the integrated version of Cognos Business Intelligence v10.2.2 within Tivoli Common Reporting?

answers.text: the integrated version of Cognos Business Intelligence v10.2.2 within Tivoli Common Reporting supports Firefox Quantum v60 in compatibility mode.

qas.question: How can this issue be fixed?

answers.text: To fix this issue, access the Tivoli Common Reporting dispatcher link: https://JazzSM_hostname:port/tarf/servlet/dispatch.

paragraphs.context:
Useful Information: For users who prefer reading in German, a translation is accessible [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg22000565]. 
Context: jazzsm1122relnotes; jazzsm1132relnotes; jazzsm1133relnotes; jazzsm1140relnotes; jazzsm1150relnotes; jazzsm1151relnotes; jazzsm1200relnotes; TECHNOTE (TROUBLESHOOTING)
ISSUE(ABSTRACT) IBM® Cognos® Analytics Studio in IBM Jazz for Service Management's Dashboard Application Services Hub and Tivoli® Common Reporting Version 3.2 and subsequent fix packs fail to initiate on Firefox® Quantum Version 60. UNDERLYING REASON The IBM Jazz for Service Management framework contains the Dashboard Application Services Hub service and the Tivoli Common Reporting service. Dashboard Application Services Hub supports Firefox Quantum v60 because its bundled libraries like Dojo are compatible with Firefox Quantum v60. But, the integrated version of Cognos Business Intelligence v10.2.2 within Tivoli Common Reporting supports Firefox Quantum v60 in compatibility mode. Launching Tivoli Common Reporting from Dashboard Application Services Hub triggers browser mode compatibility issues, causing Cognos Analytics Studio functions to malfunction. qas.question: In a clustered environment, what is the correct order of restarting the servers after adding a new property?

answers.text: In environments with clustering, the Secondary ImpactServers must be stopped before initiating the restart of the Primary ImpactServer. Restarting the Secondary ImpactServers after this process ensures the new property is distributed to all servers in the cluster and prevents it from being overridden.

Context:

Add the parameter: impact.[EventReaderName].filterapplied=true, where [EventReaderName] represents the name of the EventReader in lower-case (for example: servereventreader). Once this property is included in the file, a restart of the ImpactServer is necessary for activation. 

In environments with clustering, the Secondary ImpactServers must be stopped before initiating the restart of the Primary ImpactServer. Restarting the Secondary ImpactServers after this process ensures the new property is distributed to all servers in the cluster and prevents it from being overridden.

This issue is related to using the Filter Analyzer and does not impact the ability of the EventReader to parse the Filter. If you are unable to observe the applied filter in the generated SQL for the EventReader refer to the tech note "EventReader filters not reflecting in SQL select statement" [link below].

paragraphs.context:
The settings configuration:system. [DebugModuleName].traceOutput=true is to be modified, where [DebugModuleName] stands for the lower-case specific debug module name (an example might be: systemupdatecheck). Post the modification in the settings file, a restart of the SystemServer is warranted to implement the changes.

In case of working in a Dispersed System environment, it is advisable to halt the Server Nodes first, then put a stop to and reboot the Main SystemServer, followed by resuming the Server Nodes. This is to guarantee that the configured settings are not overridden while ensuring that the adjustments reach each SystemServer in the Dispersed System.

It is important to acknowledge that this problem is associated with the utilization of Debug Viewer and does not interfere with Debug Module's ability to evaluate the trace. In situations when you are incapable of observing the trace in effect for Debug Module, you are recommended to look up the TechNote "Debug Module traces not reflecting on the system Update" [link given below].

qas.question: Where can you find the setting to increase the default pool of threads in DASH application?

answers.text: the configuration file located at $NCHOME/etc/precision/NcPollerSchema.cfg/update

paragraphs.context:
In the latest versions of the DASH application (v3.8 and higher), there's an important upgrade feature known as the version info updater. This can be accessed by running <JazzSM Home>/ui/bin/consolecli.sh Version, which creates an output file. Please make sure to upload this output file to your account on the PMR platform for record-keeping and troubleshooting purposes.

Also, in the upgraded versions v3.8 and v3.9, there's the capability to create additional threads by modifying the default setting. This is due to the enhancement of the Thread Pool feature. For instance, the default pool of 100 threads can be increased as needed - modify and uncomment the line in the configuration file located at $NCHOME/etc/precision/NcPollerSchema.cfg/update and update the value for BatchExtraThreads as desired.

qas.question: What is the new enhancement in version 4.0 related to data tracker threads?

answers.text: The new enhancement in version 4.0 facilitates the creation of additional data tracker threads. However, for earlier versions like v3.9, it's pertinent to mention that there is no feasibility for extra tracker threads. If you employ v4.0, it allows for the same thread pool size (for instance, 200) to be used when additional data trackers are established.

qas.question: How can you elevate the pre-set number of threads in v4.0?

answers.text: In v4.0, you can also elevate the pre-set 200 threads by altering a particular code line in the $SYS_HOME/config/tracker/ThreadSchema.cfg file.

qas.question: What about the feasibility of extra tracker threads in v3.9?

answers.text: for earlier versions like v3.9, it's pertinent to mention that there is no feasibility for extra tracker threads.

paragraphs.context:
The new enhancement in version 4.0 facilitates the creation of additional data tracker threads. However, for earlier versions like v3.9, it's pertinent to mention that there is no feasibility for extra tracker threads. If you employ v4.0, it allows for the same thread pool size (for instance, 200) to be used when additional data trackers are established. In v4.0, you can also elevate the pre-set 200 threads by altering a particular code line in the $SYS_HOME/config/tracker/ThreadSchema.cfg file. Navigate through the file and uncomment this specific line: //update config.setting set DataExtraThreads = 250;

TECHNOTE (FAQ)
QUESTION: What are the files that necessitate change while updating, upgrading, moving, or migrating a Data Manager PostgreSQL database in IBM Business Intelligence System Monitor 6.0?
ANSWER: The files include:
$SYS_HOME/data_mgr/cfg/data_mgr_skills.cfg
$SYS_HOME/data_mgr/cfg/data_mgr_server.cfg
$SYS_HOME/.product_info/BI_SERVER.setting
$SYS_HOME/event_servant/cfg/db-config.json
$SYS_HOME/gui/cfg/db-config.json
$SYS_HOME/init_database/cfg/db-config.json
It's crucial to understand that a manager might be set up to verify the status of the manager's database server, and thus, the PostgreSQL database server name would also be outlined in this file: 
$SYS_HOME/data_mgr/misc/cmdtable_comparison.ctb
Please remember: If there are changes in the port, username, or password, these modifications should be mirrored in the aforementioned files.

SUPPORT INFO (FAQ)
QUESTION: Which files need to be revised when enhancing, relocating, updating or transitioning an Oracle database in the IBM Business Process Management System 6.3? 
ANSWER: Following files are to be modified: 
$IBM_ROOT/bpm_rex/cfg/bpm_rex_finca.cfg
$IBM_ROOT/bpm_rex/cfg/bpm_rex_srv.cfg
$IBM_ROOT/.prodinfo/FSM_SERVER.settings
$IBM_ROOT/eventserver/cfg/db-cfg.xml
$IBM_ROOT/gui/cfg/db-cfg.xml
$IBM_ROOT/initdb/cfg/db-cfg.xml
In certain situations, a monitor could be set-up to watch over the status of the monitor's database server. In such cases, the Oracle database server name is also stated in this file:
$IBM_ROOT/bpm/misc/cmdtab_merged.ctb.
Please keep in mind: If the port, user, or password changes, these must also be updated in the mentioned files.

qas.question: How can users ascertain if a table was initially created as 'Not Logged' using the db2cat command?

answers.text: Users can apply the db2cat command i.e., db2cat -db <dbname> -n <TableName> -s <Schema> -t. If the output under 'Table not logged' reads '1', the table was created as NLI.

qas.question: How do you use the db2look command to check if a table was created as "NOT LOGGED INITIALLY"?

answers.text: the db2look command to obtain DDL data regarding the table, which would also reveal if the table was generated as "NOT LOGGED INITIALLY". Example: `db2look -d <database_name> -t <table_name> -e -o <output_file_name.out>`.

qas.question: Does the LOG_ATTRIBUTE column in the SYSCAT.TABLES table still confirm if a table was created as NOT LOGGED INITIALLY in DB2 V9 and onwards?

answers.text: from DB2 V9 onwards, this column will always have a value of 0.

qas.question: Where can more information on NOT LOGGED INITIALLY be found?

answers.text: Further information on NOT LOGGED INITIALLY is available at [http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSAE4W_7.1.0/com.ibm.etools.iseries.langref2.doc/rbafzmst484.htm].

paragraphs.context:
IBM's Fix Central platform [https://www.ibm.com/support/fixcentral/quickorder?] offers a range of assistance regarding software patches and fixes, such as the 6.3.1.13-TIV-ITM_SQL-IF0001 version updated on May 14, 2018. Comprehensive details including fixed problems (APARS) such as IJ00815, IJ00433, IJ01540 are provided in these links [/support/docview.wss?uid=swg24044840&aid=2].

To ascertain if a table was initially created as 'Not Logged', DB2 offers two methods. Users can apply the db2cat command i.e., db2cat -db <dbname> -n <TableName> -s <Schema> -t. If the output under 'Table not logged' reads '1', the table was created as NLI. The second method employs the db2look command to obtain DDL data regarding the table, which would also reveal if the table was generated as "NOT LOGGED INITIALLY". Example: `db2look -d <database_name> -t <table_name> -e -o <output_file_name.out>`. However, alterations to the table with ACTIVATE NOT LOGGED INITIALLY will not be indicated by these commands as it only activates NLI for current unit of work. It's important to note that the LOG_ATTRIBUTE column in the SYSCAT.TABLES table was formerly used in DB2 V8 to confirm if a table was created as NOT LOGGED INITIALLY, but from DB2 V9 onwards, this column will always have a value of 0. Further information on NOT LOGGED INITIALLY is available at [http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSAE4W_7.1.0/com.ibm.etools.iseries.langref2.doc/rbafzmst484.htm].

qas.question: How can you determine if a table is in NOLOGGING mode in Oracle databases?

answers.text: you can query the DBA_TABLES view as follows: SELECT LOGGING FROM DBA_TABLES WHERE TABLE_NAME = '<table_name>';

qas.question: What does the LOGGING column report?

answers.text: The LOGGING column would report YES if the table logs all the changes and NO if it was created with the NOLOGGING clause.

qas.question: How can you extract the DDL for a table?

answers.text: you can use the dbms_metadata.get_ddl function to extract the DDL for a table, which will display if the table was created with the NOLOGGING option. Example: SELECT dbms_metadata.get_ddl('TABLE','<table_name>') FROM DUAL;

qas.question: What happens when the ALTER TABLE command is used?

answers.text: the ALTER TABLE command can modify a table to become a NOLOGGING table

qas.question: What could be the reason for an issue during the startup process?

answers.text: it could be due to the lack of communication with the necessary applications.

qas.question: What consequence does this startup issue cause?

answers.text: it prevents specific tasks from completing in time for the Portal to launch.

qas.question: How can this startup issue be rectified?

answers.text: Navigate to the WAS Admin Console > Applications > Monitor the applications > Specific Application Server > Under the segment, check the box for the WebSphere_Portal server> Select Enable Auto Start > Save changes> Restart Portal.

qas.question: What should be done after the necessary changes have been made?

qas.question: How can the provided additional information be helpful?

answers.text: This information could provide a better understanding of the problem and possible solutions.

paragraphs.context:
When encountered with an issue during the startup process, it could be due to the lack of communication with the necessary applications. This issue is noticeable as it prevents specific tasks from completing in time for the Portal to launch. In order to rectify this, we recommend making the necessary changes that would facilitate in the resolution of this problem. Navigate to the WAS Admin Console > Applications > Monitor the applications > Specific Application Server > Under the segment, check the box for the WebSphere_Portal server> Select Enable Auto Start > Save changes> Restart Portal. Following this procedure, retry the upgrade process.

Added information for further reference involves the interconnection of Segment Product Component Platform Versions ranging from 7.5, 8.0, 8.0.1, to 8.5 Business Integration IBM Operational Decision Manager and versions like 7.1 of Business Integration WebSphere ILOG JRules Not Applicable. This information could provide a better understanding of the problem and possible solutions.

qas.question: What may cause the behavior of scripts to vary?

answers.text: This could be due to different environment variables or resource restrictions such as ulimit setting in Linux.

qas.question: What is required to ensure that tools and commands work consistently across different operational scenarios?

answers.text: a comprehensive system-level understanding is necessary

qas.question: Where can you refer for understanding ulimits and their implications?

answers.text: You can refer to further readings like the user guide offered by Linux - IBM SDK 7.0

qas.question: What utilities may require access to large sparse files?

answers.text: certain utilities such as SIQ may require access to large sparse files

qas.question: What can the usage disk space increase to during operations?

answers.text: The usage disk space may increase equal to the original file size during these operations.

qas.question: What is necessary to ensure optimal system performance?

answers.text: A careful consideration of file size is necessary to ensure optimal system performance.

paragraphs.context:
"The behavior of certain scripts can vary when run from a script execution tool rather than directly from the shell interface. This could be due to different environment variables or resource restrictions such as ulimit setting in Linux. Therefore, a comprehensive system-level understanding is necessary to ensure that tools and commands work consistently across different operational scenarios. You can refer to further readings like the user guide offered by Linux - IBM SDK 7.0 and others for understanding ulimits and their implications.[http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/java7sdk/v7r0/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.java.lnx.70.doc%2Fuser%2Fulimits.html] 

On a similar note, certain utilities such as SIQ may require access to large sparse files, requiring significant disk space. The usage disk space may increase equal to the original file size during these operations. A careful consideration of file size is necessary to ensure optimal system performance."

paragraphs.context:
This context provides an exhaustive list differentiating the version specifications for the IBM WebSphere MQ or WMQ. It offers a detailed breakdown of the support matrix for each release across various platforms including Solaris, Windows, Linux, HP, and AIX. The matrix incorporates the unique versions of GSKit Level and Java Runtime Environment (JRE) levels corresponding to each release. In addition to the system specifications data for each version, the data covers the continuous delivery and long-term support release models, highlighting essential versioning details such as release number, corresponding GSKit Level, JRE Level, and the client level. This holistic contrast between different version releases can help users better understand the evolution of the software.

Furthermore, the information about specific command line executions and the actions required to be taken for setting the ulimit values demonstrate the degree of customization and flexibility provided by the IBM SDK. The specification of ulimit requirements in the command line gives users a clear guideline for optimal software functioning. The related information topics provide significant resources for users to further understand the intricacies and nuances of ulimit values, thereby enlightening them about the system limitations imposed on resources.

PRODUCT DOCUMENTATION 
ABSTRACT 
When an attempt is made to upload a file size of more than the prescribed limit in the Web Deployment interface, an unanticipated error code ICWDP1022E appears on the screen. 
CONTENT 
As a temporary solution, ensure that the file size being uploaded does not surpass the pre-established limit. If a larger file needs to be uploaded, consider dividing the file into smaller sections.

qas.question: What configurations are specified at <SERVER_ROOT>/config?

answers.text: Any configurations specified here will apply to all services within the domain.

qas.question: What does the <DOMAIN_ROOT>/config store and handle?

answers.text: This location stores configurations that are only applicable to the specific domain and its services.

qas.question: What is the protocol if the same configuration is found in both <DOMAIN_ROOT>/config and <SERVER_ROOT>/config locations?

qas.question: What must be done if a configuration is modified?

answers.text: If a configuration is modified, it is essential to restart the server for changes to take effect.

paragraphs.context:
USER PRIVILEGES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Each user is responsible for understanding the security implications of their actions. Any compromise in security, either intentional or accidental, must be immediately reported to the relevant authorities. 

SERVER CONFIGURATION: The server configuration profile that is active depends on two directories: 

1) <SERVER_ROOT>/config: Any configurations specified here will apply to all services within the domain. 

2) <DOMAIN_ROOT>/config: This location stores configurations that are only applicable to the specific domain and its services. 

If the same configuration exists in both <DOMAIN_ROOT>/config and <SERVER_ROOT>/config locations, the one in <DOMAIN_ROOT>/config will have the priority. If a configuration is modified, it is essential to restart the server for changes to take effect. 

Note: The authentication and operational authority for WebSphere MQ, WebSphere Process Server, WebSphere Service Registry, and all other Business Integration products reside in the hands of IBM Business Process Manager Standard, WebSphere Enterprise Service Bus, and WebSphere Partner Gateway Advanced Edition.

System administrators must be careful around the configuration of WebSphere Application Server (WAS), to ensure seamless communication across all SIB (Service Integration Bus) entities.

qas.question: In case a parameter is specified at both the SERVER_ROOT/parameters and the SUBSYSTEM_ROOT/parameters locations, which one will have priority?

answers.text: the parameter defined at <SUBSYSTEM_ROOT>/parameters will have priority.

paragraphs.context:
<SERVER_ROOT>/parameters : The parameters set under this location are intended to apply to the entire server system environment. If a parameter is established here, it will be universally applicable to all subsystems across the server.
<SUBSYSTEM_ROOT>/parameters : Parameters set in this location would be specific to each subsystem available within the server. They govern only the specific subsystem they are associated with. 

In the case where a parameter is specified at both the <SERVER_ROOT>/parameters and the <SUBSYSTEM_ROOT>/parameters locations, the parameter defined at <SUBSYSTEM_ROOT>/parameters will have priority.

After modifying any parameter, it is necessary to reboot the server system for the changes to take effect.

paragraphs.context:
To check the version of your installed WebSphere Application Server, use the IBM Administrative Console and follow these steps: Navigate to System Administration ---> Nodes ---> [Your Node] ---> Server Types ---> WebSphere application servers ---> [Your Server] ---> Java and Process Management --> Process definition ---> Java Virtual Machine. Once there, the Java SDK section will provide you with the version information.

If you need to check on your messaging engine’s status or details in a distributed environment, you can follow these instructions: First, open your WebSphere Application Server Admin Console and proceed to these locations: Service integration ---> Buses ---> [Your Bus] ---> Messaging engines ---> [Your Engine]. There you will find the status info, as well as other valuable settings details.

paragraphs.context:
ERROR: "SystemFailedException.java: cd: .credentials_store: [File or directory not found]". The issue can be resolved by adjusting the PATH variables in the operating system environment during the creation of Java Exception files or .jars. 

Example Context: It is essential to have a unique user id parameter for admin.authenticate.PDServerMethod in the admin_portal.properties file. In order to avoid any discrepancies, it is important to follow these steps before you initiate the ‘create-admin-ssl’ command: 

a) Use a unique id for admin.authenticate.PDServerMethod 

or 

b) Launch the following command manually from a terminal on the admin server to remove the admin_id value from the Access Control Manager repository: 

java com.tivoli.pd.jcfg.AdminSslCfg -action reconfigure-admin_id system_admin -admin_pwd ****** -admin_id youradminid -port 7326 -mode local -policysvr <hostname>:7242:1 -authzsvr <hostname>:7243:1 -cfg_file D:\IBM\WebSphere\Tomcat\java\jre/PdAuth.properties -key_file 

For more information, please follow this resource
#Creating the AMJRTE properties file [http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wpdoc/v6r2m0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.wp.ent.doc/security/cfg_tam_auth.html]
